title: McDonald's staff alerted police after waiter used drive-thru while drink driving
text:

McDonald's staff tipped off the police after a Harvester waiter used the drive-thru while drink driving.

Alexander Brunditt had drunk a 35cl bottle of whisky at the end of his shift before getting in the car and driving 20 miles home.

Brunditt stopped at the Uttoxeter McDonald's drive-thru on the A50 in Stoke-on-Trent, where staff could tell he had been drinking and informed the police.

Lynne Warrington, prosecuting, said: "Information initially came from a manager at McDonald's.

"At 12.10am Mr Brunditt drove into the drive-thru. He appeared to be under the influence of alcohol . Police were contacted and an officer spoke to the defendant. He was asked if he had been drinking.

"Mr Brunditt said he had been drinking and he had driven from Stoke-on-Trent to Uttoxeter. The officer said the defendant's speech was slurred and his eyes were glazed. He was arrested."

(Image: Stoke-on-Trent Live)

The court heard that Brunditt, of Balance Hill, Uttoxeter, gave an alcohol reading of 94 micrograms in 100 millilitres of breath, Stoke-on-Trent Live reports .

The legal limit is 35.

Brunditt admitted drink-driving following the incident, on Monday, September 23.

The court heard that he works for the Harvester chain of restaurants in Stoke-on-Trent.

Mitigating, Neil Davies said: "There is no underlying problem with alcohol. He tells me he hasn't drunk a drop since this incident."

Deputy district judge John Maxwell ordered the Uttoxeter man to complete 100 hours unpaid work and disqualified him from driving for 22 months.

He told Brunditt: "I'm genuinely sorry to see you here before me having your character tarnished in this way, but this is a serious offence.

"Sitting there drinking a bottle of whisky and driving off is little short of writing a suicide note.

"You are a young man of good character who comes from a good family. I hope this is a blip."

Brunditt was also ordered to pay £135 court costs and a victim surcharge of £90.
